title: Rotational work - torsional spring rotates rod

content.description: A torsion spring is fixed to the end of a rod of rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub R" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <msub> <mi>I</mi> <mtext>R</mtext> </msub> </mstyle> </math>. The torsion spring is fixed to a horizontal table with negligible friction, as shown in the Top View. When the rod is displaced an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math> from equilibrium, the torsion spring exerts a restoring torque of magnitude <math alttext="tau equals 2 kappa times theta squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>κ</mi><msup><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="kappa" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>κ</mi></mstyle></math> is a positive constant with appropriate units. After being displaced by an angle <math alttext="theta sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, the rod is released and rotates through its equilibrium position with angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
